paper_title.en: Report on BIPM/CIPM Key Comparison CCAUV.U-K4: Absolute Calibration of Medical Hydrophones in the Frequency Range 0.5 MHz to 20 MHz Final Report
Absolute Hydrophone Calibration to 40 MHz Using Ultrasonic Far-Field

description.en: An absolute hydrophone calibration technique using ultrasonic far-field with optical interferometry was extended to 40 MHz to evaluate the sound pressure amplitude generated by medical ultrasound equipment. A 1-mm nominal radius plane transducer was the calibration sound source for an ultrasonic far-field at 50 mm propagation distance at 40 MHz. The transducer's effective radius was 0.88 mm at 40 MHz, with a range of 10-40 MHz. A coplanar membrane hydrophone with a 0.2 mm radius active element was calibrated using the technique at frequencies of 10-40 MHz with a 1 MHz frequency interval. Calibration results obtained using the developed system were compared with those obtained using our current calibration system. The discrepancy between those results was within the uncertainty of our current calibration system for frequencies of 10-20 MHz.

paper_title.en: Effect of Circular Assumption on Active Element Size Measurement for Hydrophone Sensitivity Calibration Using Narrow Beam

description.en: The effect of the hydrophone active element size measured assuming circular geometry on the sensitivity calibration using a narrow beam is investigated. It is confirmed that there is a hydrophone that has a noncircular effective active element despite its circular geometry, by measuring the effective radii of a hydrophone for the direction turned with a step of 5 degrees on the active element. As a result of calibrating the hydrophone sensitivities using a focused beam and measured element radii, the sensitivity dispersion due to the circular assumption is identified as an important uncertainty source of the measurement. (c) 2010 The Japan Society of Applied Physics

paper_title.ja: レーザー超音波による精密音速測定と半導体プロセスの温度計測への応用
paper_title.en: Precise Sound Velocity Measurement Using Laser Ultrasound and its Application for Temperature Measurement in Semiconductor Processing
Surface breaking crack evaluation with photorefractive quantum wells and laser-generated Rayleigh waves

description.en: An adaptive laser ultrasound system using optical two-wave mixing technique with photorefractive quantum wells is developed for crack characterization in noisy environments. AlGaAs/GaAs photorefractive multiple quantum wells featuring a quick response time of 9.1 mu s cancel disturbances below 100 kHz. A laser-generated Rayleigh wave in a thermoelastic regime is used for crack characterization. The positions and depths of artificial cracks, 3 and 5 mm in depth and 0.2 mm in width, were evaluated. The crack orientations were also determined using a shear wave that was generated through mode conversion of a Rayleigh wave at the crack tip. (c) 2006 American Institute of Physics.

paper_title.en: Influence of ultrasonic nonlinear propagation on hydrophone calibration using two-transducer reciprocity method

description.en: In this study, the influence of ultrasonic nonlinear propagation on hydrophone calibration by the two-transducer reciprocity method is investigated quantitatively using the Khokhlov-Zabolotskaya-Kuznetsov (KZK) equation. It is proposed that the correction for the diffraction and attenuation of ultrasonic waves used in two-transducer reciprocity calibration can be derived using the KZK equation to remove the influence of nonlinear propagation. The validity of the correction is confirmed by comparing the sensitivities calibrated by the two-transducer reciprocity method and laser interferometry.

publication_name.en: JAPANESE JOURNAL OF APPLIED PHYSICS PART 1-REGULAR PAPERS BRIEF COMMUNICATIONS & REVIEW PAPERS

paper_title.en: Non-contact sound velocities and attenuation measurements of several ceramics at elevated temperatures

description.en: Laser ultrasonic technique has been employed to carry out the sound velocities and attenuation measurements as a function of temperature in alumina, two kinds of silicon nitride and partially stabilized zirconia (PSZ) samples. Accuracy of the laser technique used has been checked in terms of the diffraction effect and reproducibility of the results. Results of attenuation at room temperature have been compared with quartz transducer technique. In PSZ, velocity behavior has become non-linear and also, a peak in attenuation has been observed around 500 degreesC. In one of the silicon nitride sample, which uses glassy sintering agent, attenuation has shown a sharp peak around 950 degreesC. Interestingly, when the experiment was repeated from 800 to 1000 degreesC, this anomalous attenuation peak has disappeared, leaving a background increasing towards higher temperatures. (C) 2002 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Sound velocity measurements of high and ultra-high pure iron as function of temperature by using phase conjugate technique

description.en:
Conventional ultrasonic measurements require contact transducers. Many problems originate in the form of the use of couplant during measurements at high temperatures and study of pure metals, for example; 1) Suitable fluid couplant does not exist for use above 500degreesC. Several other alternative methods have been used by many researchers such as buffer rods, momentary contacts etc. in order to surmount this difficulty. 2) Many fluids for ultrasonic coupling can affect the surface of the specimen and hence, pure metals as an example can loose purity during ultrasonic investigations. In the light of this situation, it is highly desirable to carry out the experiment in such a way that couplant is not at all used during high temperature sound velocity measurements of high and ultra-high pure iron samples. One possible way to obtain such a data is to use lasers as remote sensors for generation and detection of acoustic waveforms.
It has been observed that surface of pure iron samples become rough when they are heated above alpha-gamma phase transformation temperature. This makes it very difficult to obtain the high temperature sound velocities data by employing usual laser interferometer techniques which requires polish surface of the samples. This problem has been taken care of by using phase conjugate technique employing BaTiO3 crystal as phase conjugate mirror for the detection of the acoustic waveforms. Acoustic waveforms have been generated in high and ultra-high pure iron samples by using Q-switched Nd:YAG pulsed laser beam. Ablation has been observed on the surface of the samples during exposure to pulsed laser beam. Timing measurements had been made by taking 10% of the peak height point on the rising edge of the longitudinal pulse. Results obtained have been compared with the earlier reported ultrasonic velocity measurements of iron.

publication_name.en: ISTM/2003: 5TH INTERNATIONAL SYMPOSIUM ON TEST AND MEASUREMENT, VOLS 1-6, CONFERENCE PROCEEDINGS

paper_title.en: Narrowband generation of ultrafast acoustic and thermal transients in thin films for enhanced detectability

description.en: A technique for the narrowband generation of ultrafast acoustic and thermal transients in thin films is demonstrated; this technique allows for enhanced detectability of these transients. The approach pursued uses a reduced-bandwidth, optical pulse train for excitation that is constructed from a series of time-delayed pulses derived from a single-laser pulse. The underlying physical limitations of this approach are considered in order to assess conditions under which successful bandwidth reduction can be realized. Results in an aluminum thin film on a tungsten-carbide substrate show successful generation and detection of a narrowband acoustic signal centered at 32.34 GHz.

publication_name.en: IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON ULTRASONICS FERROELECTRICS AND FREQUENCY CONTROL

paper_title.en: Spectral compression of ultrafast acoustic transients in thin films for enhanced detectability

description.en: Experimental results showing the generation of ultrafast acoustic transients in thin films demonstrate the production and use of an optical pulse train for excitation that enhances signal detectability. Results in an aluminum thin film on a tungsten-carbide substrate show generation and detection of a narrow-band acoustic signal centered at 32.34 GHz. It is shown that the signal-to-noise ratio of the recorded transient is improved by a factor of 1.7 when simple digital bandpass filtering at the center frequency is performed. The physical limitations of this approach are considered in order to assess conditions under which significant bandwidth reduction can be realized. (C) 2001 American Institute of Physics.

paper_title.en: Neural network-based inverse analysis for defect identification with laser ultrasonics

description.en: This paper describes an application of the neural network-based inverse analysis method to the identification of a surface defect hidden in a solid, using laser ultrasonics. The inverse analysis method consists of three subprocesses. First, sample data of identification parameters versus dynamic responses of displacements at several monitoring points on the surface are calculated using the dynamic finite-element method. Second, the back-propagation neural network is trained using the sample data. Finally, the well-trained network is utilized for defect identification. Fundamental performance of the method is examined quantitatively and in detail, through both numerical simulations and laser ultrasonics experiments. Locations and depths of vertical defects are successfully estimated within 12.5% and 4.1% errors relative to the specimen thickness, respectively.

paper_title.ja: Neural network-based inverse analysis for defect identification with laser ultrasonics(共著)

paper_title.en: Precise sound velocity measurement by laser ultrasound and its application to temperature measurement of solid materials

description.en: A sound velocity measurement system based on high frequency laser ultrasound has been developed. The system employs a 140 MHz ultrasonic rf burst generated using a mode-locked laser and pulse-echo-overlap method for precise velocity measurement. As an application, longitudinal velocity in a [100] silicon single crystal 0.45 mm thick was measured with a precision of 160 ppm at room temperature.

paper_title.en: Optical detection of ultrasound with a phase-modulated Michelson interferometer

description.en: A phase-modulated Michelson interferometer for optical detection for ultrasound is described. The operating point of the interferometer is kept to the minimum intensity of the interference pattern. This scheme allows the use of a high power laser to improve the sensitivity without a photodiode saturation. Ultrasonic displacement amplitudes as small as 10 pm can be detected when the maximum intensity on the photodiode is 100 mW. The detected root-mean-square noise is twice as much as the theoretical prediction of 3 x 10(-16) m/root Hz. The ultrasonic wave forms excited with a transducer and a pulsed laser in a Si sample are presented. (C) 1999 American Institute of Physics. [S0034-6748(99)01911-5].

paper_title.en: Ultrasound detection by using a confocal Fabry-Perot interferometer with phase-modulated light

description.en: The optical detection of ultrasound with a radio-frequency (RF) sideband type of optical discriminator is described. The sidebands are produced on a laser beam by an optical phase modulator. A confocal Fabry-Perot interferometer with a lens at the mid-point in the cavity has been used to provide frequency discriminator functions. The cavity is tuned to the maximum transmission point, and then the RF beat signal in the back-reflection beam is detected. The ultrasound signals are obtained from the phase changes between the detected RF signal and the modulation source. Several experimental results are presented. (C) 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Ultrasonic velocity measurements in molten materials with the use of laser-generated ultrasound

description.en: A novel approach for measurements of sound velocity at high temperatures in solid and molten materials is presented. The sample is contained by a transparent fused quartz cell, through which the laser-generated ultrasound is probed by an optical method. A Michelson-type interferometer is adopted for the faithful detection of the ultrasonic waveforms. The interferometer is combined with a phase conjugator, which converts a scattered beam from the sample into a well collimated beam, thus the ultrasound on a diffusing surface is easily detected at a distance. The temperature dependences of the longitudinal velocity in Sn and Ge have been obtained. The uncertainties in the velocity measurement for the Sn sample have been estimated to be 0.34% and 0.48% in the solid and molten phases, respectively.

paper_title.en: Measurements of sound velocities at high temperatures by using laser generated ultrasound

publisher.en: PLENUM PRESS DIV PLENUM PUBLISHING CORP

paper_title.en: OPTICAL-DETECTION OF ULTRASOUND ON ROUGH SURFACES BY A PHASE-CONJUGATE METHOD

description.en: We describe an optical method to detect ultrasonic waves on materials with rough surfaces. Scattered beams from the rough surfaces are changed to the spatially coherent ones by a phase conjugate technique. A Michelson interferometer with a flat frequency response is adopted for faithful detection of the waveforms. The present method is applied to plasma-sprayed materials with the roughness of 10 mu m. Longitudinal and surface waves are fairly detected, and the surface waves are then analysed in the frequency domain to deduce the dispersion curves. Experimental results on two alumina coatings prepared with different spray distances are demonstrated.

paper_title.en: Surface wave calibration of acoustic emission sensors with laser-generated ultrasound

description.en: Laser-generated surface wave is employed as a standard acoustic emission (AE) source to calibrate sensors. By choosing an appropriate laser-intensity, a nearly unipolar pulse with 100 ns duration was successfully realized. The surface excitation is measured by an optical interferometer and AE sensors simultaneously. Comparing these both outputs, the sensitivity of the sensors can be deduced in the wide frequency range. Experimental results on eight commercial sensors are demonstrated. © 1994, Acoustical Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: Journal of the Acoustical Society of Japan (E)

paper_title.ja: Optical-detection of transient Lamb waves on rough surfaces by a phase-conjugate method
paper_title.en: Optical detection of transient lamb waves on rough surfaces by a phase- conjugate method
